definitions.definition: to leave and never to return to
definitions.example: We had to abandon the car as it broke down

definitions.definition: to stop doing or having (something)
definitions.example: She had to abandon her plans for a vacation
definitions.synonyms: discontinue, surrender, withdraw, quit, relinquish, renounce, forgo, abdicate

definitions.definition: the place where someone lives
definitions.example: The cottage became their abode for the summer
definitions.synonyms: home, house, domicile, residence, dwelling, habitation

definitions.definition: extremely silly, foolish, or unreasonable
definitions.example: The manager rejected the absurd proposal
definitions.synonyms: crazy, foolish, illogical, irrational, ludicrous, preposterous, wacky

definitions.definition: a large amount of something
definitions.example: The food supply was in abundance at the party
definitions.synonyms: affluence, bounty, myriad, plenty, plethora, prosperity, wealth
definitions.antonyms: few, lack, little, need, poverty, scarcity

definitions.definition: to stick to something, to attach firmly to something
definitions.example: The mud adhered to his shoes

definitions.definition: friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to
definitions.example: He impressed all with his affable mannerism
definitions.antonyms: disagreeable, discourteous, impolite, nasty, rude, unsociable

definitions.definition: the ancient past, especially the period before the Middle Ages
definitions.example: The great civilizations of antiquity

definitions.definition: an object, building, or work of art from the ancient past
definitions.example: A museum of Roman antiquities

definitions.definition: anxious or fearful that something bad or unpleasant will happen
definitions.example: I'm a bit apprehensive about tomorrow's meeting

definitions.definition: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring
definitions.example: He went through a long and arduous training program

definitions.definition: into pieces; apart
definitions.example: He split the log asunder with an axe

definitions.definition: to declare or state (something) in an open and public way
definitions.example: They avow their support for the Labour party
definitions.synonyms: assert, declare, state, attest, swear, vow, insist, confess, admit

definitions.definition: to force (someone) to leave a country as punishment
definitions.example: The dictator banished anyone who opposed him

definitions.definition: to get rid of (something)
definitions.example: They banished red meat from their diet

definitions.definition: not producing fruit or not able to produce fruit
definitions.example: Persistent droughts caused the land to become barren

definitions.definition: having very few plants
definitions.example: A barren desert

definitions.definition: not producing good or useful things, ideas, etc
definitions.example: An artist who is going through a barren period

definitions.definition: a mountain stream
definitions.example: The sound of the trickling beck joined with the voices of the birds
definitions.synonyms: branch, rill, rivulet, creek, streamlet, river, brook

definitions.definition: a gesture used to signal, summons or direct someone
definitions.example: He has few servants at his beck and call

definitions.definition: hostile and aggressive
definitions.example: He was disliked because of his belligerent behaviour

definitions.definition: engaged in a war or conflict
definitions.example: belligerent nations
definitions.synonyms: warring, combatant, fighting, conflicting, clashing, quarrelling

definitions.definition: to surround a city, building, etc, with soldiers and try to take control of it
definitions.example: The army besieged the castle

definitions.definition: surround and harass
definitions.example: The politician was besieged by the media

definitions.definition: to make many requests or complaints about something
definitions.example: The television station was besieged with calls

definitions.definition: quick and rude in manner or speech
definitions.example: His secretary was rather brusque with me
definitions.synonyms: curt, abrupt, blunt, short, sharp, terse, peremptory, gruff

definitions.definition: an event that causes great harm and suffering; disaster
definitions.example: Emergency measures may be necessary in order to avert a calamity
definitions.synonyms: adversity, cataclysm, catastrophe, collapse, hardship, misfortune, woe
definitions.antonyms: advantage, benefit, blessing, boon, miracle, success, wonder

definitions.definition: move swiftly and in an uncontrolled way
definitions.example: The car careered across the road and went through the a hedge.

definitions.definition: occupation undertaken for a significant period of a person's life
to fill the cracks or holes in (something) with a substance that keeps out water
definitions.example: He carefully caulked the area around the windows

definitions.definition: to decide how a dancer or group of dancers will move during a performance
definitions.example: She choreographed the ballet routines beautifully

definitions.definition: mercy; lenience
definitions.example: The victim's family asked the court not to give clemency to their son's murderer

definitions.definition: to persuade someone gently to do something or go somewhere, by being kind and patient, or by appearing to be
definitions.example: It took almost an hour to coax the cat down from the tree

definitions.definition: to begin
definitions.example: The festivities will commence with a parade
definitions.antonyms: close, complete, conclude, end, finish, stop

definitions.definition: to prevent something from being seen or known about
definitions.example: She could barely conceal her anger on hearing brusque remarks
definitions.synonyms: bury, camouflage, cloak, cover, lurk, mask, stash, stow

definitions.definition: excessive pride in oneself
definitions.example: The conceit of that man makes him unattractive

definitions.definition: an idea that shows imagination
definitions.example: The director's brilliant conceit was to film this tale in black and white

definitions.definition: to criticize something or someone strongly, usually for moral reasons
definitions.example: The school condemns cheating, and any student caught cheating will be expelled

definitions.definition: a large destructive fire
definitions.example: The conflagration destroyed several historic buildings before it was extinguished

definitions.definition: a war or conflict
definitions.example: The treaty is the latest attempt to resolve the ten-year conflagration

definitions.definition: to keep and protect something from damage, change, or waste
definitions.example: To conserve electricity, we are cutting down on our  heating

definitions.definition: to plan secretly with other people to do something bad, illegal, or against someone's wishes
definitions.example: He felt that his colleagues were conspiring together to remove him from his job.
definitions.synonyms: plot, scheme, plan, intrigue, collude, connive, cooperate

definitions.definition: a feeling that someone or something is not worthy of any respect or approval
definitions.example: Because she came from a wealthy family, it was not surprising she looked at homeless people with contempt

definitions.definition: speech or behaviour that does not show proper respect to a court or judge
definitions.example: She was arrested for contempt of court

definitions.definition: traditional and ordinary
definitions.example: Instead of the conventional white wedding dress, the bride insisted on a garish shade of purple
definitions.synonyms: normal, standard, regular, ordinary, usual, traditional, typical, common
definitions.antonyms: abnormal, different, irregular, rare, uncommon, unusual

definitions.definition: not openly acknowledged or displayed
definitions.example: The spy went to great lengths to make sure his enemies would not discover his covert plans
definitions.synonyms: clandestine, secret, furtive, hidden, surreptitious, undercover

definitions.definition: to want to have something very much, especially something that belongs to someone else
definitions.example: She always coveted power but never quite achieved it.

definitions.definition: making a pretence of shyness or modesty that is intended to be alluring
definitions.example: She looked at him with a coy smile of invitation

definitions.definition: eager to know or learn something
definitions.example: The boy was curious to find out what his parents had bought him for Christmas

definitions.definition: strange, unusual or unexpected
definitions.example: She found a curious old clock in the attic

definitions.definition: question (someone, typically a soldier or spy) about a completed mission or undertaking
definitions.example: The witness was debriefed about the crime scene

definitions.definition: dishonest behaviour, behaviour that is meant to fool or trick someone
definitions.example: We were angry when we discovered that her excuse was really a deceit
definitions.antonyms: fairness, forthrightness, frankness, honesty, sincerity, trustworthiness

definitions.definition: done consciously and intentionally
definitions.example: It was a deliberate shot, fired after much thought
definitions.synonyms: intentional, calculated, conscious, intended, planned, knowing, wilful, purposeful, premeditated

definitions.definition: engage in long and careful consideration until you reach a conclusion
definitions.example: She deliberated over the menu to decide her order

definitions.definition: to completely destroy a building, especially in order to use the land for something else
definitions.example: A number of houses were demolished so that the supermarket could be built

definitions.definition: to prove that an argument or theory is wrong
definitions.example: He completely demolished all her arguments

definitions.definition: a building where supplies or vehicles, especially buses are kept
definitions.example: a bus depot

definitions.definition: a place for the storage of large quantities of equipment, food or goods
definitions.example: storehouse, warehouse, garage

definitions.definition: in a very poor condition as a result of disuse and neglect
definitions.example: The cities were derelict and dying
definitions.synonyms: damned, doomed, dilapidated, ramshackle, run down, abandoned, deserted, delinquent

definitions.definition: negligent, slack, irresponsible
definitions.example: The guards were derelict in their duty

definitions.definition: to dislike (something or someone) very much
definitions.example: I despise marmite and refuse to eat it!
definitions.antonyms: accept, admire, adore, approve, cherish, praise, respect

definitions.definition: without money, food, a home, or possessions
definitions.example: His business failures left him destitute
definitions.synonyms: bankrupt, exhausted, impoverished, indigent, needy, penniless, poor

definitions.definition: an object or machine that has been invented for a particular purpose
definitions.example: A barometer is a device to measure air pressure
definitions.synonyms: gadget, tool, appliance, apparatus, instrument, machine

definitions.definition: a plan, scheme, or trick with a particular aim
definitions.example: Writing a public letter is a traditional device for signalling dissent
definitions.synonyms: ploy, tactic, move, plot, plan, trick, ruse, manoeuvre

definitions.definition: a loud, unpleasant, and prolonged noise
definitions.example: The fans made an awful din at the music concert
definitions.synonyms: noise, racket, rumpus, ruckus, cacophony, uproar, commotion

definitions.definition: a state of disorganisation or untidiness
definitions.example: The guests left her house in total disarray

definitions.definition: throw (someone or something) into a state of disorganisation or untidiness
definitions.example: The unexpected inspection disarrayed the usual schedule

definitions.definition: to make something known publicly, or to show something that was hidden
definitions.example: They disclosed her name to the press
definitions.synonyms: reveal, divulge, impart, admit, confess, leak, unveil

definitions.definition: depressing; dreary
definitions.example: The dismal weather made the late afternoon seem like evening
definitions.synonyms: dingy, dim, dark, gloomy, dreary, drab, dull, bleak
definitions.antonyms: bright, cheerful, clear, encouraging, happy, pleasant

definitions.definition: to go or move in different directions, to spread apart
definitions.example: The clouds dispersed, revealing blue sky above
definitions.synonyms: distribute, discharge, dislodge, dispel, dissipate, scatter, sprinkle

definitions.definition: a disagreement or argument
definitions.example: They have been unable to resolve the dispute over working conditions
definitions.synonyms: bickering, brawl, conflict, controversy, debate, disagreement, discord, feud, friction, quarrel, squabble, wrangle

definitions.definition: to engage in an argument or debate
definitions.example: They disputed on which is the best football team

definitions.definition: causing dislike or disgust; offensive; unpleasant
definitions.example: Customers complained about the distasteful odour
definitions.synonyms: abhorrent, hateful, obnoxious, repugnant, unpalatable, unsavoury
definitions.antonyms: agreeable, pleasant, tasty, attractive, delicious, delightful, savoury

definitions.definition: a feeling of extreme worry, sadness, or pain
definitions.example: The patient showed no obvious signs of distress
definitions.synonyms: anguish, suffering, pain, agony, ache, affliction, torment

definitions.definition: a situation in which you are suffering or are in great danger and therefore in urgent need of help
definitions.example: Donations were given to families in distress

definitions.definition: a prolonged period of abnormally low rainfall; a shortage of water resulting from this
definitions.example: This year's drought was devastating to cotton growers

definitions.definition: a prolonged dearth or shortage
definitions.example: A drought of good talent

definitions.definition: a house, apartment, or other place of residence
definitions.example: There is an estimated shortfall of some five million dwellings across the country

definitions.definition: not using a lot of fuel, money, etc.; avoiding extravagance
definitions.example: An economical way to heat your house would be by using thermostats

definitions.definition: to not be caught by someone
definitions.example: The thief was able to elude the police

definitions.definition: to fail to be achieved by (someone)
definitions.example: Victory has eluded us

definitions.definition: to fail to be understood or remembered by (someone)
definitions.example: I know who you mean but her name eludes me

definitions.definition: to hold someone in your arms as a way of expressing love or friendship
definitions.example: He embraced her warmly to comfort her

definitions.definition: to accept (something or someone) readily or gladly
definitions.example: This was an opportunity that he would embrace

definitions.definition: to include something often as one of a number of things
definitions.example: Charity embraces all acts of generous giving

definitions.definition: to appear by coming out of something or out from behind something
definitions.example: She emerged from the sea, blue with cold

definitions.definition: to become known, apparent, important, or prominent
definitions.example: She has emerged as a leading contender in the field

definitions.definition: to have someone work or do a job for you and pay them for it
definitions.example: How many people does your company employ?

definitions.definition: to use something
definitions.example: She employed a pen for sketching wildlife

definitions.definition: to spend time doing something
definitions.example: He was busily employed in lacing up his shoes

definitions.definition: to seriously or conditionally try to do (something)
definitions.example: The school endeavours to teach students to be good citizens

definitions.definition: a serious effort or attempt
definitions.example: His endeavours have gone unrewarded

definitions.definition: to continue to exist in the same state or condition
definitions.example: This tradition has endured for centuries

definitions.definition: to experience (pain or suffering) for a long time
definitions.example: He endured five years as a prisoner of war

definitions.definition: to deal with or accept (something unpleasant)
definitions.example: We endured the lecture for as long as we could

definitions.definition: a short journey that you take to do or get something
definitions.example: I have to run some errands for my mom this afternoon
definitions.synonyms: task, job, chore, assignment, mission, expedition

definitions.definition: the making of a judgment about the amount, number, or value of something; assessment
definitions.example: The teacher carried out the evaluation of pupils at year end
definitions.synonyms: appraisal, assessment, calculation, decision, interpretation, opinion

definitions.definition: a short trip especially for pleasure
definitions.example: They went on a brief excursion to the coast
definitions.synonyms: cruise, expedition, jaunt, outing, picnic, tour, trek, trip

definitions.definition: to officially force (someone) to leave a place or organization
definitions.example: She was expelled from school for bad behaviour
definitions.synonyms: discharge, dismiss, eject, eliminate, evict, suspend

definitions.definition: to push or force (something) out
definitions.example: expel air from the lungs

definitions.definition: the state or process of a species, family, or larger group being or becoming extinct
definitions.example: The extinction of the dinosaurs was caused by an asteroid impact 65 million years ago

definitions.definition: to remove or take out, especially by effort or force
definitions.example: the fossils are extracted from the chalk

definitions.definition: to get (information, a response, etc.) from someone who does not want to give it
definitions.example: We finally extracted a confession from him

definitions.definition: to get (a substance) from something by the use of a machine or chemicals
definitions.example: The machines extract the juice from the apples

definitions.definition: using or consisting of facts
definitions.example: She gave a clear and factual account of the attack to the police
definitions.synonyms: accurate, credible, descriptive, legitimate, precise, valid
definitions.antonyms: careless, false, inaccurate, invalid, questionable, wrong

definitions.definition: a situation in which many people do not have enough food to eat
definitions.example: The long draught was followed by famine

definitions.definition: causing death
definitions.example: a disease that is often fatal
definitions.synonyms: deadly, lethal, mortal, terminal, incurable, malignant

definitions.definition: causing ruin or failure
definitions.example: She made a fatal mistake/error
definitions.synonyms: disastrous, devastating, ruinous, catastrophic, calamitous, dire

definitions.definition: the state of being very tired; extreme weariness
definitions.example: We were overcome by fatigue after the long journey

definitions.definition: to make (someone) tired
definitions.example: We were fatigued by the long journey

definitions.definition: very weak
definitions.example: She's still feeble from her long illness

definitions.definition: not good enough; not successful or effective
definitions.example: a feeble joke/excuse

definitions.definition: pretend to be affected by (a feeling, state, or injury)
definitions.example: He feigned sickness so he wouldn't have to go to school

definitions.definition: producing many plants or crops
definitions.example: Fields are very fertile along the flood plains of the river

definitions.definition: producing many new and inventive ideas
definitions.example: He has a fertile mind

definitions.definition: able to produce children, young animals, etc.
definitions.example: a fertile cow/bull

definitions.definition: very confident in behaviour, and liking to be noticed by other people
definitions.example: The writer's famboyant lifestyle was well known
definitions.synonyms: exuberant, confident, lively, animated, vibrant, vivacious

definitions.definition: brightly coloured and easily noticed
definitions.example: His clothes were rather flamboyant for such a serious occasion
definitions.synonyms: colourful, bright, vivid, dazzling, splashy, gaudy, garish, jazzy, flashy

definitions.definition: run away from a place or situation of danger
definitions.example: He was forced to flee the country

definitions.definition: the plants of a particular region, habitat, or geological period
definitions.example: Africa's flora is dictated by the local climate, and its natural vegetation is, therefore, very varied

definitions.definition: to grow or develop successfully
definitions.example: Wild plants flourish on the banks of the lake

definitions.definition: to hold up and show (something) in an excited or proud way
definitions.example: Dressed as a pirate, he entered the stage flourishing his sword

definitions.definition: rise and fall irregularly in number or amount
definitions.example: Her wages fluctuate between £150 and £200 a week

definitions.definition: an enemy or opponent
definitions.example: After a fight, the two best friends turned foes
definitions.synonyms: enemy, adversary, opponent, rival, antagonist, competitor

definitions.definition: to order (someone) not to do something
definitions.example: I forbid you to go
definitions.synonyms: ban, censor, deny, deprive, disallow, proscribe, restrict

definitions.definition: to say that (something) is not allowed
definitions.example: The museum forbids flash photography

definitions.definition: not important: not deserving serious attention
definitions.example: She thinks window shopping is a frivolous activity

definitions.definition: silly and not serious
definitions.example: Hannah's frivolous apology was not accepted

definitions.definition: a feeling of appreciation or thanks
definitions.example: Let me express my sincere gratitude for all your help

definitions.definition: seriously bad
definitions.example: This violation of school rules is a grave matter

definitions.definition: to cause (someone) to feel sad or unhappy
definitions.example: Her decision to live overseas grieved her mother

definitions.definition: to feel or show grief or sadness
definitions.example: People need time to grieve after the death of a family member
definitions.synonyms: mourn, lament, sorrow, cry, sob, weep

definitions.definition: comically or repulsively ugly or distorted
definitions.example: She brought a grotesque mask for the Halloween party
definitions.synonyms: absurd, bizarre, eerie, ludicrous, monstrous, odd, outlandish, preposterous, whimsical

definitions.definition: a part of the ocean, a lake, etc., that is next to land and that is protected and deep enough to provide safety for ships
definitions.example: Fishing in the harbour, we could see many ships

definitions.definition: to give home and shelter to someone
definitions.example: He was suspected of harbouring an escaped prisoner
definitions.synonyms: shelter, conceal, hide, shield, protect, suppress

definitions.definition: to have (something, such as a thought or feeling) in your mind for a long time
definitions.example: She started to harbour doubts about the wisdom of their journey

definitions.definition: done or made very quickly
definitions.example: I made a hasty sketch of the scene
definitions.synonyms: quick, hurried, fast, swift, rapid, speedy, brisk

definitions.definition: acting too quickly
definitions.example: He later realized that he was too hasty in his decision to quit

definitions.definition: the shape formed by a line that curves around and along a central
definitions.example: spiral, coil, corkscrew, curl, twist

definitions.definition: an act that is meant to trick or deceive people
definitions.example: The bomb threat is probably a hoax, but we should still evacuate the building
definitions.synonyms: practical joke, jest, prank, trick, ruse, deception, fraud, bluff, spoof, scam, setup

definitions.definition: to deceive, especially by playing a trick on trick on someone
definitions.example: People were hoaxed by the website

definitions.definition: a strange or unusual habit, way of behaving, or feature that someone or something has
definitions.example: One of his little idiosyncrasies was always preferring to be in the car first
definitions.synonyms: eccentricity, mannerism, peculiarity, trait, quirk, whimsy, freak

definitions.definition: not having enough knowledge, understanding, or information about something
definitions.example: He was told constantly that he was ignorant and stupid
definitions.synonyms: illiterate, naive, innocent, oblivious, obtuse, uneducated, uninformed

definitions.definition: to behave in a similar way to someone or something else, or to copy the speech or behaviour, etc. of someone or something
definitions.example: Her style has been imitated by many other writers
definitions.synonyms: ape, duplicate, echo, emulate, impersonate, mimic, mirror, mock, replicate, reproduce, resemble

definitions.definition: to put (something) in a liquid so that all parts are completely covered
definitions.example: Immerse the fabric completely in the dye

definitions.definition: to make (yourself) fully involved in some activity or interest
definitions.example: She had immersed herself in writing short stories

definitions.definition: failing to show proper respect and courtesy, very rude
definitions.example: The boy was punished for his impudent behaviour

definitions.definition: unable to be heard
definitions.example: The loud noise of the machinery made her voice inaudible

definitions.definition: marking the beginning of an institution, activity, or period of office
definitions.example: His inaugural concert as music director was a huge success
definitions.synonyms: opening, first, begin, initiate, launch, introductory, maiden

definitions.definition: begin or introduce (a system, policy, or period)
definitions.example: The museum was inaugurated on September 12

definitions.definition: a cut made in something
definitions.example: The sculptor delicately decorated the marble with incisions

definitions.definition: (medical) a cut made into the body during surgery
definitions.example: The surgeon made an abdominal incision during a gall bladder operation

definitions.definition: not clearly visible or attracting attention
definitions.example: The red-brick building was inconspicuous and blended with the surrounding buildings
definitions.synonyms: unobstructive, unnoticeable, unremarkable, unspectacular, unostentatious, unimposing, undistinguished, unexceptional, modest, unassuming, discreet, hidden, concealed

definitions.definition: lower in rank, status, or quality
definitions.example: Schooling in inner-city areas was inferior to that in the rest of the country

definitions.definition: a person lower than another in rank, status, or ability
definitions.example: How dare she treat him as an inferior

definitions.definition: a person or animal that lives in or occupies a place
definitions.example: London is a city of over eight million inhabitants

definitions.definition: not harmful or offensive
definitions.example: While you may think bullying is innocuous, it leaves a lasting scar on its victim

definitions.definition: rude or impolite; having or showing a lack of respect for other people
definitions.example: Insolent behaviour will not be tolerated

definitions.definition: of extreme force, degree, or strength
definitions.example: Her job demands intense concentration

definitions.definition: having or showing strong feelings or opinions
definitions.example: He is an intense young man determined to do very well
definitions.synonyms: passionate, ardent, fervent, fiery, energetic, fanatical

definitions.definition: to explain the meaning of (something)
definitions.example: We need someone to interpret these results for us

definitions.definition: to understand (something) in a specified way
definitions.example: I interpreted his behaviour to mean that he disliked me

definitions.definition: ask questions closely, aggressively, or formally
definitions.example: The suspect was interrogated (by the police) for several hours

definitions.definition: the process or fact of isolating or being isolated
definitions.example: Isolation from family and friends may also contribute to anxiety

definitions.definition: workers considered as a group
definitions.example: These candles are made by sweated labour

definitions.definition: physical or mental effort
definitions.example: The price of repairs includes labour and parts

definitions.definition: the process by which a woman gives birth to a baby
definitions.example: She went into labour this morning

definitions.definition: to express sorrow, regret, or unhappiness about something
definitions.example: She lamented over the loss of her best friend
definitions.synonyms: bemoan, deplore, regret, wail, sob, grieve

definitions.definition: coming or happening near the end of a process, activity, series, life, etc.
definitions.example: We'll go in the latter half of the year
